A unit test should test a unit. A unit i=
s whatever concept or portion
of functionality makes sense within the conte=
xt of your code base.

In some systems, a unit test might test a method, in=
 others it might
test a group of inter-operative objects.

For example. I'm=
 writing a small string handling library and each
method of my library gets=
 it's own test. Whereas at the day job, I
often find myself testing either =
a whole object or a group of objects.
It really does depend on what makes s=
ense for your system and the
granularity of the concepts and functionality =
that it contains.

Perhaps this is why J.B. prefers the term "programmer te=
sts" instead
of unit tests. Because no one can agree on what a unit actuall=
y is,
but most programmers know what needs to be tested.

 gets a turn now.
